markdownRemark.html:
I have recently quite enjoyed the use of TODO comments (or TODOs). I get that on the one hand there is something really off-putting about having TODOs littered all over your code base. Like threads of thought that did not have time to fully develop and are now dangling appendages of what could have been if only someone had finished the job at time, but for whatever reason could not. This, in my view, is a totally valid use of a TODO comment.

At their worst TODOs are things that I would rather avoid placing in code for other’s to pick up later or leave as an excuse for something half done. Usually a standard comment is more appropriate and should be used liberally in cases where code may be in a state that is hard for new readers to reason about.

At their best TODOs are indicators of future work in the code itself. It could be a brief description of a feature or a simple indicator that standard protocol was skipped for the sake of brevity — in my case writing front-end code may call for the addition of high quality copy that end users will read, but may not be worth spending time on now because this version of your contribution (usually in the form of a PR) is not finalized.

I would like to propose that a TODO can be most effective not when the yet-to-be-built thing is ill-conceived, but rather it is precisely at its most useful when others can read the code, encounter the TODO and exclaim “YES! That would be a great next iteration”.
